course.subject: COMP
course.name: Computer and Communication Security
course.description: Cryptosystems, symmetric-key and public-key cryptography, cryptanalysis, authentication, message digests, digital signatures, and random number generation. Access controls and firewalls. Applications such as certificate authorities, electronic commerce, smartcards, and digital cash.
course.prerequisites: COMP 3711 OR COMP 3711H

reviews.author: Tommy Li
reviews.title: 404 Workload Not Found
reviews.comment_content:
Lots of old-schooled content regarding computer security. If you want to learn new stuffs, go for shuai's version of COMP 3632 (that's a good one!).

The first part of the course is mostly math tools and ciphers. Basically, he repeats all the discrete math stuff from MATH 2711. I don't think there is any new content, maybe keyed hash functions and modes of operation? Feel free to comment if you find sth new.

The second part is just explaining security protocols one by one. Unix, windows NT, kerberos, ssh, ipsec, ssl, ...... Lots of uninteresting details that probably would not be useful.
reviews.comment_teaching:
He explains things clearly. He spend quite a lot of time to go through the details and make things clear. Also, he tries to ask questions to make sure we understand the content.

However, no one bothers to answer his questions (or even bother to listen to his lectures) due to his tone. I don't know why. His voice just makes me feel bored.
reviews.comment_grading:
Most people get 9X% score in the three assignments, so the grading is mostly based on the final exam. AND THE FINAL EXAM ONLY CONSISTS OF NINE MULTIPLE CHOICE QUESTIONS. The conceptual questions are very tricky. For the factual questions, the content even have been mentioned briefly (or have not been mentioned?) in the lecture. This is a completely inaccurate reflection of the students' ability.

I misread a word in a tricky question and got fxxked up in the factual questions, resulting only 5/9.

My score:
Assignment (45%): 299/300
Final (55%): 5/9
Final grade: A-

Grade distribution:
A+: 1
A: 2
A-: 2
Total A-range: 5
B+: 7
B: 2
B-: 0
Total B-range: 9
C+: 3
Total C-range: 3
No D/Fs

Basically the grading curve is nice but the assessment scheme is problematic.
reviews.comment_workload:
This course has the least workload among all UST course. The course only consists of 3 written assignments and an open-book exam.

For the 3 assignments, you can find the answers of most (if not all) questions from past homework. Your job is basically try to understand the answer and do paraphrasing.

The exam only consists of 9 MC questions and it is open-book. I think revision would not help you much unless you try to rewatch every lecture video and mark down all of the details (which is mission impossible).

reviews.title: Easy for B but Not Easy for A
reviews.comment_content:
From basic crytography to real world crytographic systems.

First half is teaching the basic mathematics & algorithms in crytography.

Second half is teaching about the real world practical systems, like the UNIX, WINDOWS, INTERNET, IPSec, SSL, SSH...

The mathematics used in this course is not hard and light in fact. (DIFFERENT from what the professor said: many maths involved...) For example, some number theory theorem like Euler's theorem, Fermat Little theorem, which is useful in the proof of some crytographic algorithms.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I think DING 's teaching is quite well prepared as he know his materials very well.

As he say, "I teach the courses for many years. "

I like the style of his notes of the first half part, which is so tidy, with appropriate math proof.

He teach on the topics slowly and thus not covered a lot of details.
reviews.comment_grading:
Attendance 5%
Assignments 30 %, 10% each
Final exam 65 %

"一試定生死"的感覺...

Very Generous in terms of b range (only few c range...),
Not so generous in terms of a range (~15% only...and it is a small class you know...).
Seems no one fail in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
3 assignments, 每份大概花1-2天時間.
不過，落手做先知concept 出問題。 （唔知係唔係每個人都有咁既感覺啦～...）

reviews.author: LemonLemon
reviews.title: Good grade and light workload course
reviews.comment_content:
I studied Comp3632 and Comp4632 before taking this course. I think overall it is the easiest cybersecurity course.

The content can be separated into 2 main parts: Cryptography and Security Protocols. They are as follows:
- Mathematic Foundations (Things you learned in Comp2711)
- One-key Block Ciphers
- Key management for One-key Cophers
- Public-key Cryptography and RSA
- Public-key infrastructure
- Key distribution protocol
- Hash Functions and Keyed Hash Functions
- Several Security Protocols
- Kerberos Authentication Protocol
- Mail Security
- Access Control
- Identification and Authentication
- Unix Security
- IP Security
- SSL
- Firewalls
- VPN
- SSH
- DDoS
----------------------------------------
My thought is, the content of this course is easy. It's just theory, and Prof introduced it very briefly.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think Prof Ding is quite experienced. Slow and boring pace, but things are explained clearly. However, I give a lower score because the PowerPoint slides lack detail. You need to pay extra attention in his lectures since he always gave the key points verbally instead of writing them in his slides. At the same time, the content is brief in this course. If you really want to understand those topics, you need to take so much time to read several textbooks and search the internet. (Although the exam will not ask for that detail)
reviews.comment_grading:
In-Class Quiz: 32%
Assignment: 28% (4 assignments in total)
Exam: 40%

A Range: ~25%
B Range: ~55%
The lowest grade is C+. Good grade among all Comp Courses. I don't know whether it is because this course had fewer students. Only 1 person can get A+.

You don't need to worry about the in-class quiz. This is just for attendance purposes. The questions are pretty easy as long as you keep focusing during his lecture.
reviews.comment_workload:
The assignments only take you a few hours. The only workload is that I need to review all lecture videos. As mentioned, all details are hidden in the lecture. Instead of just reading notes, you need to jot down all the details in the lecture.
Open-book-open-computer exam, with plenty of exam time. You can actually just search during the exam.
